comments.author: Daniel Doherty
comments.comment:
Is it dodgy to use a private static variable in this way?
Doesn't look thread safe if the rule is used to validate more than one case at a time.
Also it's very hard to work out what's going on and debug: - the isValid method actually uses the variable - the atLeastOnePointOfContactSetupForEmailSubset method sets the value by calling setEmailNotificationName method with a value it got from atLeastOnePointOfContactSetupToReceiveEmails.
Is it possible to find a simplier way and avoid using a private variable completely?

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: Again, this is to do with the work that Pelham will be doing in Ballina 5 & allowing for multiple email types to be checked against. I'll give it another whirl through.

comments.author: Daniel Doherty
comments.comment: Why do we have a atLeastOnePointOfContactSetupToReceiveEmails() method that s only function is to call another atLeastOnePointOfContactSetupForEmailSubset method - should we simplify this to only one method?

comments.author: Aisling Clinch
comments.comment: The main reason for this is the stuff Pelahm will be working on in Ballina 5 to do with _Payment Failure_ & to allow for the message to be updated dynamically for multiple email types. I thought it was nicer just to call one method.

comments.author: Daniel Doherty
comments.comment:
TaEnum provides a method to check if it's in a subset so I think it's better to use this here:
caseLinkReason.containsIn(BILL_PUBLISHED_EMAIL_MANAGEMENT_SUBSET)
That way we don't need to get a list of the subset and instance variables pointsOfContactCaseLinkReasonEnum and billPublishedEmailManagementSubsetInstances can be removed.

comments.author: Daniel Doherty
comments.comment:
Same as in atLeastOnePointOfContactSetupForEmailSubset - we can use TaEnum#containsIn
Isn't this method suspiciously similar to atLeastOnePointOfContactSetupForEmailSubset?
We have to loop twice through the points of contact; couldn't we have a method that returns the OCPointOfContactFacade if one is found with reason in the subset: - we can call that and if it's null then it's NO_POINTS_OF_CONTACT_SETUP_TO_RECEIVE_EMAILS - if it's not null then check email address list to see if we raise NO_EMAIL_SPECIFIED_FOR_POINTS_OF_CONTACT_SETUP_TO_RECEIVE_EMAILS. - only need to loop through once and in one method.

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: The absence reason is blank because the original implementation use a blank entity as wrapper when multiple electives are selected. Considering we can select and edit one or more Reason Electives at the same time, when we edit more than one a new ReasonElective entity is created to be used as Wrapper for the edition process and once the edition is done the modifications done in this 'wrapper entity' are applied for the real selected reason electives.

comments.comment: Its a really small thing!! But just for clarity it might be better to change the word 'edition' to 'edit' in both cases.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Should it not be LEAVE_PLAN_REQUEST_REASON_MISMATCH?

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: Should the text read "The selected Leave Plan

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: No unit test

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
This is not a good way to do this. What if the getAbsenceReason() method name changes?!
Just use the existing method leavePlan.getMatchingLeavePlanReason(leaveRequestAbsenceReason) instead, no need for re-inveting the wheel.

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: Good point, if the getAbsenceReason() method name changes the unit test will fail :) but the getMatchingLeavePlanReason fits perfectly in this situation, Thanks for this.

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Test is not quite complete - you arent verifying the result returned from the method under test. See ReasonElectivesTest.validateReasonElectives().

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment:
I had taken a look at ReasonElectivesTest.validateReasonElectives() and I was not so happy with it, but I can do it like ReasonElectivesTest (no worries). Anyway, don't you think we are 'over unit testing' with this approach? Because unit test should isolate (with mocking) and verify only a unit (method) logic and considering there is no much logic in BO.validate() (it just calls another method), we should just verify this invocation because the logic and result from others methods will be tested by others JUnits. In my opinion, a good approach in this situation would be:
BO.validate() - just the BOValidator.validate() invocation is verified (times). AbstractCompositeValidator.validate() - verifies if all BOSubclassValidator.validate() have been invoked and the result for all of them has been properly consolidated. BOValidator.defineValidators() - verifies if all specific validators have been added properly. SelectedLeavePlanAbsenceReasonMatchValidator.validate() - verifies the real logic for the validation and the result.

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: Why this? This will be set in the first iteration?

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment:
This is here because the data model is more permissive than what the business requires.
At the moment the data model allows for you to have different "applies to" for the same applicable type. I'm just making sure that if that ever happens and exception will be thrown untill the problem is fixed.
So when the algorithm starts the first "appliesTo" value is the one from the first record, and in the first iteration everything checks out ok. In the next iteration we might have the initial "appliesTo"=true and the new "appliesTo=false" and this will be a problem.
The update of the variable doesn't really matter (could be removed) isAppliesTo = newAppliesTo;
Its just a mere "lets keep up with the latest value" (but we know the latest value needs to be the same as the first one)
What we really want to make sure is that we don't have anything like
PublicSector|AppliesTo|County PublicSector|AppliesTo|Governmental Agencies PublicSector|Doesn't Apply To|Legislative
Data model allows for this to happen, but its a requirement from the business logic that this doesn't happend because we dont know what to do in this situation.

comments.author: Hugo Dias
comments.comment: I don't know the ammount of data to process here. This seems a good place to isolate the business code that handles one record so it could be executed on a multi-thread.

comments.comment: a boolean is a primitive type, so it's always passed as a value. I don't understand this code.

comments.author: Filipe Rodrigues
comments.comment: Two validations are happening here: Rule knows only knows how to deal with a specific applicable type, and there's no invalid appliesTo value in the list of determination data. AppliesTo value is explained above.

Bigger discussion arround what to do when something unexpected happens: Log error and move on? Log error and lauch exception? Log error and return null? Case by case analysis
For this particular case, the fact that I haven't found an Absence Employer associated to a leave request, its not an exception. I just haven't found one. It might be because I haven't found and organization associated to a leave request or there's no associated active SA for the employer associated to the Leave Request, whatever happened I can't return what I was looking for.

comments.comment: Each Rule Max and Min has 2 AbsenceDataTypes associated with each ApplicableType Additional AbsenceDataType "AbsenceDataType.STRING" added to both classes, as a result have to loop through AbsenceDataType using isValidDataType before calling isIntegerDataType

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Surely isIntegerDataType shuold handle the isValidDataType check? In otherwords, we only deal with integer here ,why isnt the call to isIntegerDataType enough>?

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: Each Rule Max and Min has 2 AbsenceDataTypes associated with each ApplicableType Additional AbsenceDataType "AbsenceDataType.STRING" added to both classes, as a result have to loop through AbsenceDataType using isValidDataType before calling isIntegerDataType

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
Consider logging something here using log4j logger.
Do we need "continue" statement, would a simpler if/else not work?

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: Code refactored

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Consider adding logging as this will be hard to debug without it. Extract description and result to local variable and log it.

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: Applies/NotApplies removed from extended class

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: applies to and not applies to logic is almost identical, except for the result. Consider refactoring this to reduce duplication abd bloat.

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: Logic simplified, removed from extended class

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Extract constants for all these strings, there is no need to have them in the method. Name them SOMETHING_TEMPLATE to indicate they are a template and have %s values formatted into them at runtime.

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: Removed from extended class, ApplicableResult description to be developed at a later date

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Javadoc is wrong! Says String

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Javadoc more wrong! Says enum this time :-)

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Mehtod name is misleading.

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: Changed to isAbsenceDataTypeOfTypeInteger

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Pull this up into a parent class and make it accept parameters for long [] allowedDataTypes. Then the looping will be done in one place, rather than in every single rule.

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: isValidDataType moved into AbstractApplicabilityRule

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment:
Consider renaming class SizeMinimumRule is vague and not really good english. What about EmployerMinimumSizeRule?
Rename test class also.

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: Some applicable types were renamed, this should be renamed to 'Minimum Size'

comments.author: Trevor Higgins
comments.comment: Rename based on class renames

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: Some applicable types were renamed, this should be renamed to 'Maximum Size'

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: Any special reason for manual mocking if you could use Mockito framework to mock SizeMaximumRule and inject the services (leaveRequestService and serviceAgreementCaseService) for you?

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: Removed manual mocking

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: static import for CoreMatchers.is?

comments.author: Daniel Dardis
comments.comment: Considering it is an Unit Test, I would isolate it testing only the method checkApplicability from SizeMaximumRule. Calling the checkApplicability from the SuperClass results in more efforts to mock dependencies and can impact your test in case checkApplicability has errors.

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: only exists in the abstract AbstractApplicabilityRule and not SizeMaximumRule or SizeMinimumRule

comments.author: Robert Treacy
comments.comment: additional tests added to call validateApplicability directly on the class in question
